qas.question: Who purchased a small shop in 1835, which would eventually become Kendals?
How long did the store operate for?
Who eventually purchased and assumed operation of the store?
Who purchased a small shop in 1853, which would eventually become Kendals?
Who purchased a large shop in 1835, which would eventually become Kendals?
How long didn't the store operate for?
Who eventually sold and ceased operation of the store?

context: Also, Kendals in <b6_0>Manchester<b6_0/> can lay claim to being one of the oldest department stores in the UK. Beginning as a small shop owned by S. and J. Watts in 1796, its sold a variety of goods. <a0_0><b4_0><b5_0>Kendal Milne and Faulkner<b5_0/><b4_0/><a0_0/> purchased the business in 1835. Expanding the space, rather than use it as a typical warehouse simply to showcase textiles, it became a vast bazaar. Serving <a1_0>Manchester<a1_0/>'s upmarket clientele for <a2_0><b7_0>over 200 years<b7_0/><a2_0/>, it was taken over by <a3_0><b8_0>House of Fraser<b8_0/><a3_0/> and recently rebranded as House of Fraser Manchester – although most Mancunians still refer to it as Kendals. The Kendal Milne signage still remains over the main entrance to the art deco building in the city's Deansgate.
